name: BBCWorld
text:
Immunity is key to solving the coronavirus pandemic - it‚Äôs what the vaccine aims to provide 

But without a vaccine, if you‚Äôve already had the virus, can you catch it again?

One recent study suggests, if you are immune, it won‚Äôt be for long

[Thread]

https://t.co/bif9w8ACVp

name: BBCWorld
text:
Coronavirus immunity may be short-lived, research from King‚Äôs College London warns 

Almost all 96 participants in their study had detectable antibodies at the start, but levels began to fall over the three months of the study

https://t.co/bif9w8ACVp https://t.co/505C5HZCJR

name: BBCWorld
text:
The immune system fights off infections, like coronavirus 

There are two parts of an immune system reaction: 
ü¶†The innate immune response
ü¶†The adaptive immune response (the response that could give you protection in the future)

https://t.co/bif9w8ACVp

https://t.co/nJ5I05xA2K

name: BBCWorld
text:
If the immune response is strong enough it could leave a lasting memory which could help protect against future infection

It‚Äôs not known if people who have mild symptoms of coronavirus, or none at all, develop a sufficient immune response

https://t.co/bif9w8ACVp https://t.co/gfWlFVWyFo

name: BBCWorld
text:
T-cells are also important; research around their role is still ongoing 

One study found people testing negative for coronavirus antibodies might still have immunity, thanks to their T-cells

https://t.co/bif9w8ACVp https://t.co/cgE9eNQPlG

name: BBCWorld
text:
Immunity differs, from virus to virus

The MMR vaccine should give life-long immunity to measles

The new coronavirus - called Sars-CoV-2 - hasn‚Äôt been around long enough to know how long immunity lasts

https://t.co/bif9w8ACVp https://t.co/ptcTvAliJq

name: BBCWorld
text:
Studying other coronaviruses could give some clues

Professor Paul Hunter from the University of East Anglia says Sars studies showed it‚Äôs ‚Äúpossible that immunity will only last about one to two years, though this is not yet known for certain‚Äù

https://t.co/bif9w8ACVp https://t.co/qDq35ZYrrL

name: BBCWorld
text:
There is no guarantee that once someone has had coronavirus they are immune

Most recovered patients will have some antibodies, but they might not be the right ones, or be enough to effectively fight the infection a second time without getting sick

https://t.co/bif9w8ACVp https://t.co/6vUZXFLeJm

name: BBCWorld
text:
Understanding immunity is key to fighting coronavirus, and getting people back to normal 

But, there are lots of big questions which still need answers

Read @JamesTGallagher's full report on whether you can catch coronavirus twice: https://t.co/bif9w8ACVp
